    • Receptors
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    The cannabinoid receptor type 2 (CB2) is a class A GPCR that was cloned in 1993 while looking for an alternative receptor that could explain the pharmacological properties of Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol. CB2 was identified among cDNAs based on its similarity in amino acid sequence to the CB1 receptor and helped provide an explanation for the established effects of cannabinoids on the immune system. In addition to the immune system, CB2 has widespread tissue expression and has been found in brain, peripheral nervous system, and gastrointestinal tract. Several “mixed” cannabinoid agonists are currently in clinical use primarily for controlling pain, and it is believed that selective CB2 agonism may afford a superior analgesic agent devoid of the centrally mediated CB1 effects. Thus, selective CB2 receptor agonists represent high value putative therapeutics for treating pain and other disease states. In this Perspective, we seek to provide a concise update of progress in the field.

    1 Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cannabinoids, exemplified by molecules such as Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol (Δ9-THC, 1),(1) are known to possess potent analgesic and anti-inflammatory properties, and 1 was first identified in 1964 by Gaoni and Mechoulam as the principle bioactive component of marijuana (hashish), which has been used for centuries as both a therapeutic and recreational drug. Prior to the 1980s, cannabinoids were hypothesized to produce their effects by nonspecific interactions with cell membranes. Since that time, a number of receptors have been implicated in the biological actions of cannabinoids, mostly members of the G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) superfamily. Two of these, CB1 and CB2, have been clearly identified and characterized,(2-4) whereas others remain topics of intense research activity. The CB1 receptor is abundantly expressed in the peripheral and central nervous system and is largely associated with psychotropic effects observed with nonselective cannabinoids, thus limiting its therapeutic potential. The CB2 receptor, however, is an attractive target for the treatment of pain and inflammation, as it is expressed on immune cells as well as in the central and peripheral nervous system, and activation of this receptor does not produce a psychotropic effect. The pharmaceutical industry has made considerable efforts to dissect out the therapeutic potential of CB2 receptors versus CB1 by focusing on the discovery of high affinity, selective CB2 agonists for the treatment of pain, and the main body of the published literature is directed to this indication.
    This review provides a perspective on the structural diversity of small molecule CB2 selective agonists, including classical and nonclassical cannabinoids and endocannabinoids, for the treatment of pain with a brief introduction to other putative indications.

    2 Cannabinoid Receptors: Background, Signaling, and Expression

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Cannabis sativa is one of the oldest medicinal plants whose preparations have been used for therapeutic and recreational purposes for many centuries. In the ancient Ayurvedic system of medicine in India, the physiological effects of cannabis have included the following characteristics: is hypnotic, allays nervous disability, stimulates libido, causes mental confusion and intoxication, promotes digestion and appetite, binds the bowels, and is carminative. In ancient China, a recipe of wine and hemp was used as an anesthetic for surgical procedures. Cannabinoids are defined as ligands of the G-protein-coupled cannabinoid receptors and have been broadly classified as plant-derived or phytocannabinoids, endogenous or endocannabinoids, and chemically synthesized or synthetic cannabinoids. As has happened in many areas of drug discovery, the main bioactive constituent of Cannabis sativa, 1,(1) became the structural starting point for synthesizing chemical analogues and studying their structure–activity relationships.
    Experiments utilizing CB1 and CB2 receptor knockout mice are suggestive of the presence of additional putative cannabinoid receptors(5, 6) such as GPR18, GPR55, and GPR119. For example, the naturally occurring fatty acid derivative oleoylethanolamide (OEA) has been identified as a weak partial agonist of GPR119(7) and the endocannabinoid 2-arachidonoylglycerol (22, 2-AG, Figure 3) displays 170-fold greater potency as a GPR55 agonist than for the CB1 and CB2 homologues.(8) Besides cannabinoids, GPR55 is also a receptor for lysophosphatidylinositol(9) and 2-arachidonoyl-sn-glycerol-3-phosphoinositol.(10) While the physiological role of GPR55 remains unclear and its pharmacology is enigmatic,(11) GPR119 is strongly implicated in the regulation of metabolism(12) and body weight(7) and has been the focus of intensive drug screening efforts in the pharmaceutical industry.
    The downstream signaling mechanisms underlying CB2 receptor activation result in inhibition of adenylyl cyclase,(13) MAP kinase activation(14) via coupling to the α-subunit of Gi/o G proteins, and a transient increase in intracellular free Ca2+ levels via a PLCβ-mediated mechanism.(15) The possibility of different CB2 agonists activating distinct signaling pathways has been proposed. Two endocannabinoids 22 (Figure 3) and 23 (noladin ether, Figure 3) and the synthetic cannabinoid 14 (CP-55,940, Figure 2) induce selective trafficking of intracellular responses through CB2 receptors.(16) In transfected CHO cells, 22 shows potent activation of ERK-MAPK pathway but requires higher concentrations for inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and even higher concentrations to stimulate Ca2+ transients. In contrast, the rank order for signaling with 23 and 14 was found to be adenylyl cyclase > ERK-MAPK/Ca2+ transients. Agonist directed trafficking is not unique to CB2 and has been demonstrated for CB1,(17) as well as many other GPCRs such as the D2S dopamine receptor,(18) 5-HT2A/5-HT2C receptors,(19) and NK1 receptors.(20) Whether this phenomenon is physiologically relevant and occurs in cells expressing native CB2 receptors remains to be seen. GPCRs have been shown to have multiple active conformations,(21) and it has been predicted that the microaffinity of an agonist for each conformation will dictate the trafficking of intracellular responses. Detailed analysis of selective CB2 agonist-directed trafficking of intracellular responses in relevant cell types is likely to have a significant impact on the development of effective drugs.
    CB2 was initially identified as a peripherally restricted receptor predominantly expressed in cells of the rodent and human immune system.(4, 22-24) Subsequent data, however, indicated that this receptor is expressed in both the central and the peripheral nervous systems. In rodents, CB2 receptor expression was reported in the cerebellum, cortex, and brainstem at the mRNA level(25) and at the protein level by immunostaining in nerve cell bodies, cells involved in neuronal processes, and glial cells in the brain(26) and cerebellum.(27) In humans, CB2 receptor protein expression was shown to be on perivascular microglial cells in the brain,(28) in avulsion-injured DRG sensory neurons and controls as well as injured brachial plexus nerve fibres, in painful distal upper limb neuromas, in infant digit skin, in osteoarthritic synovium,(29) and in keratinocytes, sensory nerve fibers, and mast cells in the skin.(30) Given the expression of CB2 receptor on immune cells, it is likely to be involved in inflammation-associated pathologies. Indeed, in human multiple sclerosis (MS) plaques, expression of CB2 receptors has been reported on T lymphocytes, astrocytes, and perivascular microglia.(31) Besides MS, CB2 receptor expression has been reported in synovia of osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis patients,(32) in human osteoclasts,(33) in the colon of patients with Crohn’s disease and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD),(34) and in endometrial biopsies from women suffering from endometritis.(35)
    To understand the physiological relevance of CB2 receptors in the various disease states listed above, several tools have been deployed: CB2 receptor gene knockout mice, the use of nonselective cannabinoid agonists along with CB2 antagonists, and CB2 receptor-specific agonists and inverse agonists. CB2 receptor knockout mice have served as a powerful tool in analyzing the functional relevance of this receptor in multiple disease indications. These mice have been reported to be healthy and fertile with no gross abnormalities.(36) However, at the cellular level, they showed lower levels of splenic marginal zone B cells and CD4+ memory T cells, peritoneal B1a cells, and intestinal NK cells and NKT cells.(37)

    3 Medicinal Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    3.1 Phytocannabinoids

    3.1.1 Classical Cannabinoids

    The absolute stereochemistry of 1 was established in 1967,(38) and more than 2 decades passed before it was identified as a modulator of the cannabinoid receptors.(2-4, 39)1 is a nonselective agonist that binds to both CB1 and CB2 with a similar affinity of approximately 40 nM.(40) This natural product exhibits a wide range of therapeutically interesting physiological effects, such as analgesia, anti-inflammatory, immunosuppressive, anticonvulsive, antiemetic, and orexigenic properties. However, usage has been regulated because of its psychotropic effects and its association with illicit drug use.(41, 42) Synthetic 1, known as dronabinol or marinol, is currently approved in the United States for treating nausea and vomiting in patients receiving chemotherapy.(43)
    1 readily isomerizes to compound 2 (Δ8-THC) under acidic conditions,(44) and this product retains a similar level of affinity for both CB1 and CB2 receptors (Table 1). The majority of the syntheses and SAR studies of classical cannabinoids have been achieved utilizing this thermodynamically more stable isomer.
    Table 1. CB1 and CB2 Binding Affinitya
     Ki (nM)  
    compdCB1CB2ratio CB1/CB2ref
    140.7 ± 1.7036.4 ± 10.01.140
    247.6b39.6c1.245
    30.83 ± 0.130.49 ± 0.181.753
    40.73 ± 0.110.22 ± 0.183.340
    51990>100000.263
    64.011.00.3668
    732.3 ± 3.70170.5 ± 7.800.1969
    82.19 ± 0.891.84 ± 0.421.253
    91.2 ± 0.1b0.032 ± 0.0193874
    10>10000b32 ± 9.0>31279
    11677 ± 132b3.4 ± 1.020079
    1215850 ± 296020.0 ± 12.4>79053
    13>2000019.4 ± 3.80>100053
    a

    Human cannabinoid receptors unless otherwise noted.

    b

    Binding to rat brain or spleen cannabinoid receptors.

    c

    Binding to mouse spleen cannabinoid receptors.

    As a group, the classical cannabinoids are defined by the tricyclic terpenophenolic moiety characteristic of the parent compound, and the structures of several representative natural and synthetic classical cannabinoids are shown in Figure 1. Several manuscripts describing the early SAR efforts focused on this family of agonists are available.(46-48)
    It is well-known that the nature of substituents at the C-1, C-3, and C-9 positions play a critical role in efficient binding to the cannabinoid receptors.(49-52) SAR studies of the C-3 side chain demonstrated that a seven-carbon homologue was optimal for activity and that branched alkyl groups also led to improved binding affinity.(52) For example, the dimethylheptyl analogue (3) exhibits an approximately 50-fold improvement in activity relative to 1.(53) QSAR analysis of 1 suggests that conformational freedom of the C-3 alkyl chain is a key element driving both affinity and functional activity for the cannabinoid receptors,(54) and numerous other SAR studies have also been reported that have helped to define the requirements of the side chain.(55-61)
    The relative importance of the C-1 hydroxyl differs between the two cannabinoid subtypes, with CB1 activity depending on this group being present or replaced with another proximal hydrogen donor such as that found in compound 9 (JWH-051).(74) Synthetic cannabinoid 4(40) possesses two hydrogen donors and exhibits significantly enhanced affinity for both the CB2 and the CB1 receptors, producing many of the same pharmacological effects as 1.(62)
    A clear preference for the 6aR, 10aR enantiomer is illustrated by comparison of the in vitro data for 4 and 5 (HU-211, dexanabinol),(63) where 5 is devoid of activity at either receptor. Consistent with the in vitro data, 5 does not produce a psychotropic effect; however, this compound does possess neuroprotective and anti-inflammatory properties as a consequence of antagonism of NMDA channels.(64, 65)5 has been shown to have an excellent safety profile(66) but was not effective in a phase 3 clinical trial that explored its utility in treating severe traumatic brain injury.(67)
    Compound 6 is a water-soluble prodrug, wherein cleavage of the solubilizing 4-N-morpholinobutyryloxy group reveals the C-1 hydroxyl group and hence the active drug product.(68) The 5-cyano-1,1-dimethylpentyl motif affords improved potency and efficacy relative to the n-pentyl analogur 1 in a mouse pain model when given intravenously (ED50 = 0.02 mg/kg). This compound was also found to cause hypothermia in rodents, presumably due to some CB1 activation in the central nervous system (CNS).
    Compound 7 (CT-3, also known as ajulemic acid or JBT-101), is a dual CB1/CB2 agonist that was prepared synthetically and closely resembles the C-11 oxidative metabolite of THC.(69) This compound exhibits good affinity for CB1 in a binding assay (Ki = 32 nM) but is weakly active in a CB1 functional assay (EC50 = 927 nM, cAMP). Despite the modest CB1 functional activity, compound 7 has a more favorable CNS effect profile than 1.(46, 70) This compound was found to be well tolerated in a phase I clinical trial(71) and subsequently completed a phase II studies wherein this molecule demonstrated efficacy in reducing chronic neuropathic pain without any major adverse effects.(72)
    Cesamet (8) is a synthetic cannabinoid that is about 20-fold more potent than tetrahydrocannibinol and mimics THC’s physiological effects.(73) This compound received approval from the FDA in 1985 for treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting; however, marketing of this compound in the U.S. was delayed until 2006.
    As discussed already, preferential activation of the CB2 receptor subtype can be achieved through preparation of cannabinoids lacking the C-1 hydroxy group (e.g., 9,(74)10 and 11,(79)12 and 13(53)). Of these molecules, 9 is the least selective; however, this compound does possess improved CB2 selectivity relative to close analogues.(74-77) The same chemical modification led to a total loss of CB1 affinity in compound 10 (1-deoxy-Δ8-THC).(75, 78, 79) Compound 11 is another selective CB2 agonist (∼200-fold), which is among the most potent (Ki = 3.4 nM) in the des-hydroxyl series.(79) Methylation of the phenolic hydroxyl is an alternative approach to selectively reduce affinity for the CB1 receptor (e.g., 12).(53) Further CB2 bias can be gained from the exocyclic double bond isomer 13 (>1000-fold).(53)

    3.1.2 Nonclassical Cannabinoids

    Nonclassical cannabinoids typically refer to bicyclic or tricyclic analogues of THC that possess a heterocyclic replacement of the pyranyl ring or lack the tricyclic ring constraint entirely (Figure 2). The structure–activity relationships of the nonclassical cannabinoids are similar to those of the classical cannabinoids and point to a hydrogen bonding interaction as a key requirement for CB1 activity (Table 2).
    Table 2. Binding Affinities for Nonclassical Cannabinoidsa
     Ki (nM)  
    compdCB1CB2ratio CB1/CB2ref
    140.58 ± 0.070.69 ± 0.020.8440
    152.9 ± 1.3b,c  83
    164350 ± 3902860 ± 12301.540
    173349.03794
    182740054.050796
    195055 ± 98423.1 ± 2.1022097
    20>10000b22.7 ± 3.90>44098
    a

    Human cannabinoid receptors unless otherwise noted.

    b

    Binding to rat brain or spleen cannabinoid receptors.

    c

    [3H]SR141716A replacement.

    Compound 14 was first discovered by Pfizer in 1974(80) and is a dual CB1/CB2 agonist that binds with a similar affinity of approximately 0.6 nM at both receptors.(40) Furthermore, this molecule demonstrated excellent analgesic activity, which was superior to 1.(81, 82) Compound 14 and the radiolabeled [3H]14 isotope are among the most widely employed reference compounds utilized in the discovery and characterization of cannabinoid ligands.(39) Compound 15 is a synthetic CB1 agonist comprising a tricyclic octahydrophenanthridine motif and was found to be more potent both in vitro and in reducing a pain response in animal models in vivo when compared to 1.(82, 83) This molecule demonstrated antinociceptive effects in rats(84) and was found to be effective in an acute postoperative pain clinical trial. Interestingly, a high incidence of drowsiness was reported as a side effect of this treatment.(85)
    Compound 16 is a major constituent of Cannabis sativa and was initially described as a relatively weak cannabinoid receptor agonist that lacks psychotropic properties.(40) Subsequent reports have appeared that suggest that 16 functions as an inverse agonist in vitro.(86) Despite its modest CB1 and CB2 affinity, 16 has shown potential utility for the treatment of inflammation,(87) anxiety, and nausea,(9) as well as inhibition of cancer cell growth.(88-90) Following a favorable clinical trial examining 16 in combination with 1,(12) the formulation was approved in Canada under the trade name Sativex for the treatment of pain associated with multiple sclerosis(91) and cancer.(92) This trademark formula is currently undergoing a phase III trial for the treatment of cancer-related pain in the U.S.(93)
    Pharmos disclosed 17 (cannabinor, PRS-211375) as a synthetic cannabinoid receptor agonist with improved CB2 selectivity.(94) Cannabinor demonstrated good safety and tolerability in phase I trials, but in a subsequent phase IIa clinical trial evaluating its use for the treatment of pain, it did not meet the primary end point defined by analgesia relative to placebo.(95)
    Not unexpectedly, the 1-deoxyphenanthridine derivative 18 exhibits enhanced selectivity for CB2 versus the CB1 receptor and also has been reported to have anti-inflammatory, immunosuppressive, and analgesic properties.(96) SAR studies on a series of bicyclic resorcinols that resemble 16 revealed that the free phenol was again an important feature for maintaining CB1 receptor affinity.(97) In this series, CB2 selectivity (220-fold) was achieved for 19,(97) which is attributable to the reduced hydrogen bonding capacity of the methyl ether relative to the phenol. Compound 20, also lacking a phenolic group, exhibited excellent selectivity for the CB2 receptor (>440-fold)(98) and demonstrated anti-inflammatory and peripheral analgesic activity in a formalin-induced inflammation model in mice, which was blocked by CB2 antagonist N-[(1S)-endo-1,3,3-trimethylbicyclo[2.2.1]heptan2-yl]-5-(4-chloro-3-methylphenyl)-1-[(4-methylphenyl)methyl]-1H-pyrazole-3-carboxamide (SR144528).

    3.2 Endogenous Cannabinoids and Other Fatty Acid Derivatives

    The endocannabinoids are eicosanoids derived from polyunsaturated C20 fatty acids such as arachidonic acid and comprise amides, esters, and ethers (Figure 3). Generally, the endocannabinoids show poor to modest affinity for the CB2 receptor but are better substrates for the CB1 subtype (Table 3). The potential therapeutic value of new drug discovery efforts targeting the endocannabinoid system was the subject of a recent review.(99)
    Table 3. Binding Affinity for Human or Rodent CB1 and CB2 Receptors
     Ki (nM)  
    compdCB1CB2ratio CB2/CB1ref
    2189c371c4.240
    22472a1400d3.0112
    2321a3000d142.8120
    24912c  124
    25250a10000d40125
    2620a,c815b40.7128
    271.4a,c>2000a,c>1428130
    282.2a,c715a,c325130
    a

    Binding to rat brain or spleen cannabinoid receptors.

    b

    Binding to mouse spleen cannabinoid receptors.

    c

    With PMSF.

    d

    Human cannabinoid receptor.

    Compound 21 (anandamide, AEA), the first identified endocannabinoid, was isolated from porcine brain in 1992(100) and exhibits agonistic activity for both CB1 and CB2 with about 4-fold selectivity for CB1.(40) It is also known that 21 can activate the vanilloid VR1 ligand gated ion channel (EC50 = 630 nM),(101) and also interacts with the putative cannabinoid receptor GPR55.(8, 102) In vivo, compound 21 elicits analgesia similar to 1 in various preclinical pain models.(103-108) Synergistic antinociceptive effects by the combination of 21 with an NSAID in inflammatory and neuropathic pain models were also recently described.(109, 110) Though efficacious, this compound was relatively short acting because of competing hydrolysis of 21 by fatty acid amidohydrolase (FAAH) to give arachidonic acid and ethanolamine.(111)
    Compound 22 is an arachidonic acid ester and is considered a major signaling component of the endocannabinoid system.(16) This endocannabinoid was first isolated from canine gut and rat brain in 1995(112, 113) and is a full agonist at both CB1 and CB2 receptors. Compound 22 is much more abundant in the brain than anandamide, and initial binding studies showed an approximate 3-fold selectivity bias for CB1.(112) Other in vitro studies have shown some variability,(113) which may reflect some instability of 22 in biological media.(114) There is evidence that 22 behaves as a potent and full CB2 agonist,(115) and exogenous injection of 22 produced antinociceptive effects mediated by CB2 receptors in a model of inflammatory pain.(116) Although 22 is susceptible to FAAH mediated degradation, monoacylglycerol lipase (MAGL) appears to be the key metabolizing enzyme in the brain.(117, 118) The endocannabinoids are believed to be synthesized, and released on demand, via a process initiated by receptor activation. The biosynthetic pathways leading to production of 21 and 22 have been thoroughly described in recent review articles.(99, 119)
    Three novel endocannabinoids were subsequently isolated and characterized (23–25).(120, 123, 125) A 2-AG analogue 23 was isolated from porcine brain in 2001 (120) and later from rat.(121) Compound 23 is a CB1 agonist with a selectivity window of 143-fold over CB2 and exhibited typical CNS effects in a mouse tetrad test.(120) Although the biosynthetic pathway to 23 has been elusive, its metabolic stability and receptor selectivity have been areas of interest.(122) Compound 24, a 2-aminoethyl ester derived from arachidonic acid, was isolated from rat and possesses a differentiated tissue distribution compared withthat found for 21.(123) In vitro, this compound behaves as a partial agonist for CB1 and a full agonist for CB2; however, it functions as a CB1 antagonist in vivo.(123) Compound 25 (N-arachidonyl-dopamine) was first reported as a synthetic analogue of 21(125) and was later isolated from rat and bovine nervous tissues.(126) This compound preferentially activates CB1 over CB2,(125) and also activates the vanilloid receptors, with an EC50 of approximately 50 nM.(126) Recently, a quantitative method for the determination of a wide range of structurally differing endocannabinoids and related compounds in human plasma was reported.(127)
    Following discovery of the endocannabinoids, SAR studies were undertaken in order to improve metabolic stability and increase the CB1 selectivity of these natural ligands.(128-130) Increased amide hydrophobicity was found to produce higher affinity for CB1 receptor than was observed for anadamide.(130) Compound 26 is a chiral congener of 21 and the most potent CB1 receptor agonist in the methanandamide series.(128) This compound is approximately 4-fold more potent than 21, while the (S)-methyl isomer (not depicted) showed reduced affinity for CB1 (Ki = 173 nM). In addition to the observed potency improvement, 26 was also found to be more stable than 21 toward hydrolytic inactivation by fatty acid amide hydrolase.(129)
    The marginal CB1 selectivity of anandamide was significantly improved with the preparation of compounds 27 and 28, wherein the ethanolamide headgroup was replaced with lipophilic groups.(130) These analogues have 40- to 60-fold higher affinity for CB1 than 21, respectively, and produce the same degree of hypothermia in vivo at a dose of 1 mg/kg in mice.

    3.3 Synthetic Cannabinoids

    3.3.1 Indoles

    In the early 1990s, the Sterling Research group serendipitously identified the first novel class of synthetic cannabinoid agonists (aminoalkylindoles, AAIs) while investigating ring constrained analogues of purported COX inhibitors related to pravadoline (WIN 48098).(131-133) These agonists consisted of an indole core substituted by the lipophilic aroyl group at C3 and an aminoalkyl side chain at N-1 (Figure 4). Compound 29,(134) or WIN 55,212-2, is one of the best characterized synthetic cannabinoids from the aminoalkylindole series and has been widely utilized, along with its radiolabeled analogue, as a pharmacological tool in cannabinoid research. Compound 29 is a potent, full agonist of both CB1 and CB2 and exhibits the full range of cannabis-like effects. In rats, 29 attenuated hyperalgesia induced by heat injury(135) or capsacin(136) and also displayed antihyperalgesic activity in the partial sciatic nerve ligation model of neuropathic pain.(137)29 also exhibits antinociceptive effects in inflammatory models of orofacial pain and temporomandibular formalin tests.(138)
    Sanofi-Aventis has disclosed a structurally similar CB2 selective chemical series (e.g., 30),(139) which lacked the extra ring constraint present in 29 (Figure 4). Compound 30 exhibited a selectivity ratio of >500-fold for CB2 in both binding and functional assays. In a related effort, researchers at the University of Arizona disclosed a chiral aminoalkylindole analogue 31 (AM-1241), which was found to have favorable physicochemical properties including appreciable aqueous solubility as the hydrochloride salt.(141) This compound was selective, having an 82-fold preference for the human CB2 receptor verses human CB1 in recombinant binding assays. Furthermore, 31 retained activity at the rodent receptors (rCB2 = 280 nM and mCB1 = 3.4 nM).(140, 141) Consistent with its in vitro activity, 31 produced analgesic effects in preclinical inflammatory and neuropathic pain models.(141) Resolved enantiomers, (R)-31 and (S)-31, demonstrated species-specific in vitro and in vivo effects. Compound (S)-31 was less potent in vitro but was found to be more efficacious than either (R)-31 or the racemate in rodent pain models probably because of different functional activities [rCB2 EC50 (cAMP): (S)-31, 785 nM (agonist); (R)-31, 315 nM (inverse agonist); rac-31, 216 nM (inverse agonist)].(142) Interestingly, 31 is associated with an opioid receptor-dependent mechanism for inhibition of pain responses, wherein naloxone, and β-endorphin antiserum, inhibited the antinociceptive effects of this compound.(143)
    Compound 32 (GW-405,833) was determined to be a selective human CB2 agonist in a recombinant binding assay (>1200-fold vs CB1); however, this compound appeared to be a partial agonist, and selectivity was lower for the rat receptor (78-fold rCB2 vs rCB1).(144)32 produced dose-dependent antihyperalgesic effects in rodent models of pain such as sciatic nerve ligation (ED50 = 0.1 mg/kg, ip), skin incision (ED50 = 2.58 mg/kg, ip), and CFA-induced inflammatory pain (ED50 = 0.17 mg/kg, ip). Studies performed in CB2 knockout mice confirmed that the in vivo pharmacological effect observed was “on target”(144, 145) and was independent of opioid receptor activation.(146) In a separate study evaluating CNS effects, 32 induced catalepsy and decreased rotorod performance at the highest dose examined (100 mg/kg), which may be attributable to activation of CB1.(144)
    The SAR of the N-1 alkyl motif was extensively examined,(147, 148) and potency was maintained using a simplified n-pentyl substituent (JWH-018, CB2/CB1Ki = 2.9 nM/9.5 nM). The n-propyl analogue 33 (JWH-015) was less well tolerated but did improve selectivity for the CB2 subtype.(147, 148) This molecule was reported to reverse postoperative hypersensitivity in rats and was also found to have immunosuppressive properties.(149) Treatment with 1-[2-(morpholin-4-yl)ethyl]-2-methyl-3-(4-methoxybenzoyl)-6-iodoindole (AM630),(150) a known CB2 antagonist, blocked the antinociceptive effect observed in the hypersensitivity assay, suggesting a CB2 specific mechanism of action.
    Collectively, the indolic cannabinoids were generally limited to smaller groups in the 2-position of the indole (e.g., methyl), while larger groups usually led to a loss in activity. The naphthyl group also heavily influenced both activity and selectivity, with the methoxynaphthalene 34 significantly reducing activation of the CB1 receptor.(147, 148)
    Although many of the synthetic cannabinoids have generally favored 3-naphthoyl or 3-aroyl groups, Abbott disclosed a distinct chemical series comprising a tetramethyl cycloalkyl ketone at this position (e.g., 35–37, Figure 5).(151, 152, 154) Compound 35 (A-796260) is one example, which was found to possess receptor affinity and selectivity (192-fold) comparable to that found in other chemical series. While the pharmacokinetic properties for 35 have not been described, this compound was efficacious in a dose-dependent manner in a CFA-induced thermal hyperalgesia model (ED50 = 2.8 mg/kg, ip), a postoperative pain skin incision model (ED50 = 18 mg/kg, ip), a chronic constriction injury (CCI) sciatic nerve model of neuropathic pain (ED50 = 12 mg/kg, ip), and a monosodium iodoacetate (MIA) induced osteoarthritis (OA) pain model. At 38 mg/kg ip, the efficacy achieved in the OA model was comparable to celecoxib, and the antihyperalgesic effects of this compound were prevented upon pretreatment with a CB2 antagonist. Additionally, no significant effects on locomotor activity were observed up to a dose of 35 mg/kg ip.(153) In contrast to the agonists already discussed, the indole was much more sensitive to substitution, causing a loss in potency for both cannabinoid receptors.(152)
    The tetrahydropyranylmethyl analogue (36, R = H and R1 = H) was found to be one of the more potent CB2 agonists in this series.(152) Indolic substitution afforded significant differences in the ability of these analogues to bind and activate the receptor. The 5-fluoro derivative (36, R = F and R1 = H)(152) improved CB2 selectivity relative to 35 (CB2, Ki = 1.6 nM; CB1, Ki = 1.21 μM) and maintained comparable activity in a functional assay (EC50 = 15–50 nM). Larger 5- and 6-substituents (e.g., phenyl, -OBn), or 7-substitution, generally provided good binding affinity for CB2 but dramatically decreased agonist activity in the Ca2+ dependent FLIPR functional assay. For example, the 7-methoxy derivative (36, R = H, R1 = OCH3) had binding affinity of 0.12 nM for CB2 but was >10 μM in the FLIPR assay.(152) A subsequent publication disclosed extensive SAR information about the cycloalkyl ketone series, wherein side chain variations at the N-1 position produced potent and highly selective CB2 agonists (e.g., 37).(154)
    Bristol-Myers Squibb disclosed several indole-derived cannabinoid receptor modulators that are further defined by a bulky amide residue (e.g., 38–41).(155-157) One of the initial compounds described, 38, produced excellent CB2 agonist responses in vitro; however, this molecule was metabolically unstable because of hydrolysis of the ester.(155) SARs aimed at replacement of the ester group led to the (S)-fenchyl analogue 39, which possessed a similar level of CB2 binding affinity.(155) This analogue also showed a modest level of interaction with the CB1 subtype. Introduction of larger substituents at the indole 2-position adversely affected CB2 binding affinity, and replacement with indazole (X = N) afforded a more potent but less selective compound (CB2, Ki = 2.0 nM; CB1, Ki = 24 nM). Despite improvements in potency, the indazoles were less efficacious in vivo in a TNFα inhibition assay.(155)
    Compounds 40 and 41 belong to two separate indole-derived CB2 agonist series. A conformationally constrained indolpyridone (40) was identified as a potent cannabinoid receptor agonist and was found to produce anti-inflammatory effects in rodent models.(156) Introduction of lipophilic carboxamides in the 2-position of the indole was tolerated and defined yet another chemical series (e.g., 41).(157) Unlike other indoles, 2-carboxamide 41 was reported to retain affinity for CB2 without an N-1 alkyl substituent.

    3.3.2 Benzimidazoles

    AstraZeneca has been investigating 1,2,5-trisubstituted benzimidazoles as selective CB2 agonists for management of pain and other diseases (Figure 6, 42 and 43).(158, 159) Compound 42 was discovered as part of an HTS campaign and served as a starting point for the medicinal chemistry effort. SAR studies of the N-1 substituent revealed that various alkyl and aromatic groups were tolerated, with cyclopropylmethyl and isopentyl (43) providing an optimal balance between potency and selectivity.(159) Despite its favorable in vitro profile, 43 was a poor in vivo candidate because of low metabolic stability, oral bioavailability, and solubility.(160) SAR efforts revealed that many tertiary amides were tolerated, with secondary and primary amides causing a reduction in CB2 affinity. Potency was maintained utilizing other lipophilic replacements for the amide and pointed to a nonspecific hydrophobic binding interaction occurring in this region of the molecule.(159)
    In a related effort, Pfizer claimed 19 benzimidazole derivatives as selective CB2 agonists.(161, 162) This strategy involved incorporation of neopentyl moieties into the 2-position together with incorporation of a sulfonyl motif (e.g., 44, 45).(161, 162) Compound 45 exhibited the greatest potency of the analogues examined, with the cyclopropyl ring and primary amide being critical for activity. In spite of the widespread use of the N-cyclopropylmethyl moiety as a pharmacophore in drug discovery, some concern over the potentially reactive nature of the cyclopropyl ring was noted.(258) Pfizer also reported pharmacological evaluation in a TNBS-induced chronic colonic allodynia model in rats.(161)
    Compound 46 is a potent and selective CB2 agonist that was found to be stable in human and rat microsomes (HLM Clint < 7.0 μL min–1 mg–1 and RLM Clint < 11.2 μL min–1 mg–1) and to have a modest oral bioavailability of 21% in rat.(163) Additionally, 46 was found to have limited CNS penetration with an unbound drug brain to plasma ratio of <1%.
    RaQualia Pharma’s efforts have also focused on a benzimidazole template. These agonists are distinguished by a saturated heterocyclic sulfone (e.g., 47),(164) which was found to impart selectivity for the CB2 receptor. RaQualia is developing RQ-00202730 (structure not disclosed), a CB2 selective agonist (CB2 EC50 = 7.4 nM, CB1 EC50 > 25 μM), as a new treatment option for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).(165)
    A closely related genus of 2-tert-butylbenzimidazoles was reported by Janssen Pharmaceuticals (Figure 6).(166-168) A 2-substituent was found to influence both potency and efficacy, with the tert-butyl group offering the best balance between these two parameters. In a patent application filed by Janssen, 172 compounds were disclosed, wherein 48 was described as a potent and selective CB2 agonist (>38000-fold vs CB1).(166) A large number of aryl sulfones are described, but the pyridyl sulfone (e.g., 48), in particular, had excellent binding affinity and selectivity for CB2. In a subsequent application, pyridyl sulfone 49 was reported to be 43% orally bioavailable in rat and to have a low brain to plasma ratio (B/P = 0.1).(167) Furthermore, 49 did not produce any CNS effects that could be attributed to activation of the CB1 receptor. Compound 49 has been reported to inhibit CYP2C9 and CYP2C19 however, and optimization of this chemical series is ongoing.
    Cycloalkyl sulfone 50 was prepared in the context of the 2-tert-butylbenzimidazole SAR and was found to retain single digit nanomolar agonist activity in a CB2 cyclase assay.(168) CB1 related effects of 50 were examined in a hypothermia experiment, wherein the lowest acceptable dose (LAD) was >40 mg/kg.
    A recent publication from Pfizer described the identification of a CNS penetrating, CB2 selective agonist for treating pain without the effects associated with the CB1 receptor.(163) SAR studies led to the discovery of a new benzimidazole (51) with improved profiling selectivity over the hERG channel (hERG [patch clamp] IC50 = 63 μM), excellent oral bioavailability (F = 100%), and significant CNS exposure in rat ([brain]u/[plasma]u = 1.0).(163) In a separate disclosure, a series of imidazotetrahydropyridines were prepared and found to be selective CB2 agonists.(169) A lipophilic efficacy (LipE = pEC50 – clogP) analysis was introduced as a useful tool for design of potent and metabolically stable CB2 agonists. In terms of affinity for CB2, sulfonamides (e.g., 52) were superior to other functionalities such as carbamates, ureas, and amides.(169) The methyl analogue (52, R = CH3) was 10-fold more potent versus 52 (R = H) in rats.
    In a separate report from Pfizer, it was shown that the potency and selectivity associated with the benzimidazoles could be maintained utilizing a benzimidazolone motif (Figure 7, 53–55).(170) One of the early hits, 53 (n = 0), was found to be a potent, selective, and full agonist for CB2, but it suffered from poor metabolic stability. Interestingly, the quinazolinone analogue (53, n = 1) showed a more favorable CB2 binding affinity (Ki = 9 nM) but was found to be an inverse agonist. Initial SAR efforts were focused on improving metabolic stability, and 54 was found to provide the best balance of CB2 affinity and metabolic stability (human liver microsomes t1/2 = 35 min). Subsequent optimization focused on the morpholine, as this moiety was found to be a major metabolic site. Replacement with a dimethylamine group, significantly improved metabolic stability (HLM t1/2 > 120 min), but this change attenuated CB2 affinity (Ki = 338 nM). Further studies led to the preparation of 55, which showed good CB2 affinity in radiolabeled binding assays for both human (Ki = 8.0 nM) and rat (Ki = 47 nM). Additionally, this compound was shown to be a full agonist for the human CB2 receptor (EC50 = 2.1 nM) and had excellent metabolic stability (HLM t1/2 > 120 min) and good oral bioavailability in rat (F = 33%).(170) In vivo, this compound suppressed visceral hypersensitivity at 3 and 10 mg/kg oral doses in the rat TNBS-induced colonic pain model. Treatment with a CB2 antagonist (SR144528) fully reversed the inhibitory effects of 55, thus supporting a CB2 mediated mechanism of action.(171)

    3.3.3 Imidazo Bicyclics

    A patent application from Merck describes imidazopyridine-based CB2 agonists (Figure 8) and their efficacy in rat models of CFA inflammatory pain and monosodium iodoacetate (MIA) osteoarthritis pain.(172) Compound 56 appears to offer the best balance between potency (EC50 = 5.4 nM), efficacy (Emax = 99.5%), and CB2 selectivity (>3100-fold).(172) Optimization of several related imidazopyridine CB2 agonists (e.g., 57, 58) was the subject of another publication.(173) Compounds 57 and 58 were evaluated in a rat model of analgesia to evaluate the impact of varying selectivity for the CB2 receptor. The selective agonist 58 (rCB2/1 EC50 = 11 nM/1068 nM) exhibited dose-dependent effects in the CFA hyperalgesia rat model, while the fully selective CB2 agonist 57 (rCB2/1 EC50 = 58 nM/>17 μM) failed to do so, despite high peripheral and central exposure. Robust efficacy in this model utilizing highly selective CB2 agonists has been reported elsewhere (e.g., 91(224)). In a related patent application, a series of 3-arylimidazopyridine analogues were disclosed, wherein 59 was the most potent CB2 agonist disclosed.(174)
    A new chemical series encompassing the imidazodiazepine 60 (n = 2) and its imidazotetrahydropyrazine (n = 1) congener was the focus of a patent application filed by Cara Therapeutics.(175) Generally, the imidazodiazepines (n = 2) were more potent and efficacious in both human and rat CB2 assays. When administered subcutaneously, 60 demonstrated analgesic activity in the murine acetic acid-induced writhing of model visceral pain and in the rat carrageenan model of acute inflammation. This molecule also produced an antiallodynic response at an oral dose of 30 mg/kg in a rat spinal nerve ligation model of neuropathic pain. In a continuing effort, structurally related imidazo fused six- or seven-membered saturated carbocycles and heterocycles were later disclosed.(176)

    3.3.4 Bicyclic Pyrazoles

    Sanofi-Aventis, Glenmark, and Janssen Pharmaceuticals have been active in advancing several pyrazole-derived cannabinoid receptor modulators (Figure 9). Sanofi’s preferred compound, 61, was reported to have about 15-fold selectivity in a functional assay.(177) Researchers at Glenmark Pharmaceuticals reported a closely related bridged pyrazole series (e.g., 62–64) and assessed several compounds in neuropathic pain models and a tail-flick analgesia study.(178, 179) Compared to Sanofi’s patent filing, the bridged pyrazole application covered a much wider scope of aryl- and alkylamides. Compound 62 was reported to be very active at the CB2 receptor, with a 1400-fold selectivity margin against CB1.(178) A subsequent PCT application claimed additional amide compositions and isosteric replacements. Compound 64 is one such example and was reported to improve in vivo exposure by about 8-fold (Cmax = 1949 ng/mL, AUC0–inf = 11 970 ng·h/mL, t1/2 = 4.8 h) relative to 63 (Cmax = 131.3 ng/mL, AUC0–inf = 1553 ng·h/mL, t1/2 = 7.3 h).(179)
    Glenmark has since advanced their CB2 program with (4S,7R)-1-(2,4-difluorophenyl)-N-(1,1-dimethylethyl)-4,5,6,7-tetrahydro-4,7-methano-1H-indazole-3-carboxamide (62, GRC-10693, tedalinab) having completed phase I trials in Europe for neuropathic pain, osteoarthritis, and other inflammatory pain disorders.(180) This isomer was reported to have similar human and rat CB2 binding affinities (Ki ≈ 12 nM) and was selective against the CB1 subtype (human, >80-fold; rat, ∼20-fold). Preclinically, this compound was found to be orally bioavailable in rat (F = 48%) and have a half-life of 5.78 h. Moreover, this molecule was efficacious in a rat FCA-induced inflammatory pain (ED50 = 1.67 mg/kg) model and was found to significantly attenuate chronic constriction injury in rats (ED50 = 2.15 mg/kg, po).(181)
    Janssen Pharmaceuticals also explored a series of cannabinoid receptor modulators that were derived from a pyrazole template. The early analogues functioned as antagonists and inverse agonists of the CB1 receptor;(182-184) however, the SAR evolved to define structural features governing CB2 receptor agonism. Pyrazole 65 (R = H) is one such example, having reduced affinity for CB1 while maintaining agonist activity for the CB2 subtype.(182) Introduction of a vinylogous sulfonamide led to 66, a CB2 selective (>550-fold) analogue, which significantly attenuated postoperative inflammatory ileus in male CD-1 mice at intraperitoneal doses of 10 and 30 mg/kg.(184) Compound 66 also reduced the impairment of gastrointestinal motility associated with the postoperative ileus. A cyclooctylpyrazole CB2 chemotype (67) resembling Sanofi’s earlier series (61) is the subject of a separate disclosure.(185) Compound 67 demonstrated significant inhibition of colitis prophylactically and therapeutically at an oral dose of 5.0 mg/kg in the oil of mustard (OM) induced colitis model in male CD-1 mice and in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) induced colitis model in female Balb/c mice.

    3.3.5 5,6-Fused Ring Related Series

    Glaxo has explored several chemical series of 5,6-fused heteroaromatic scaffolds such as imidopyridines, pyrrolopyridines, and azaindoles (Figure 10).(186-188) The azaindoles (e.g., 69) were the subject of a recent publication from GSK, describing these agonists as alternatives to their pyrimidine and pyridine CB2 chemotypes (Figure 14).(189) Morpholine 69 is a potent and selective CB2 agonist that demonstrated antihyperalgesic effects (ED50 = 0.12 mg/kg) in the acute complete Freund’s adjuvant (CFA) model of inflammatory pain. This compound was not efficacious in a rat chronic joint pain model, which the authors suggest may be attributable to low CNS penetration (B/P < 0.05). (4-((3-Chlorophenyl)amino)-1-methyl-1H-pyrrolo[3,2-c]pyridin-7-yl)(morpholino)methanone (70, GSK55441A) was subsequently identified as having good central exposure (B/P = 1.04) and retained good activity and selectivity for CB2.(189) Unlike its predecessor, 70 was efficacious in the chronic joint pain model and produced a full reversal of hyperalgesia in the CFA model at a low dose (0.1 mg/kg). This in vivo effect was subsequently attenuated upon treatment with a CB2 antagonist (AM630),(150) suggesting a CB2 receptor mediated mechanism of action. Compound 70 was further described as having a favorable pharmacokinetic profile, with a high oral bioavailability (F = 82%) and rapid absorption (plasma concentration of 1.1 μM at 0.8 h, 2.0 mg/kg po). Importantly, 70 did not cause significant hypothermia after an oral dose of 130 mg/kg, thus suggesting minimal activation of CB1.
    A CB2 chemotype comprising a purine motif was the theme of several patent applications filed by Eli Lilly (e.g., 71).(190-192) These applications describe varying substituents in the 9-position, such as tetrahydrofuranyl and tetrahydropyranyl,(190) alkylnitriles and sulfones,(191) and alkyl ethers and alcohols.(192) A related article highlighting a 9-(R)-tetrahydrofuran analogue has also recently appeared.(193) The chlorophenyl group appears to be a biased motif in this CB2 chemotype, and small, lipophilic piperazine substituents appear to be preferred (e.g., R = methyl, (fluoro)ethyl). Collectively, the agonists described in these applications were reported to have EC50 ≤ 100 nM in a CB2 GTPγS assay. Additionally, 71 was reported to reverse pain at doses of 0.3 and 1.0 mg/kg in the monoiodoacetate (MIA) induced model of oesteoathritis pain and showed antiallodynic effects at 10 mg/kg in the paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy model in rats. A dose-range finding toxicity study in beagle dogs using a single 30 mg/kg oral dose showed signs of toxicity such as vomiting, dilated pupils, decreased reticulocyte counts, and reduced excretion and food consumption. The mean AUC0–24 and Cmax were found to be 44.45 μg·h/mL and 7.54 μg/mL in this study. Lilly recently completed a phase 2 clinical trial of 8-(2-chlorophenyl)-2-methyl-6-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)-9-(tetrahydro-2H-pyran-4-yl)-9H-purine (LY2828360)(194) in osteoarthritic knee pain.(195) This molecule is reported to have similar human and rat CB2 binding affinity (human Ki = 37 nM, rat Ki = 40 nM) and is a potent and selective CB2 agonist in a GTPγS assay (CB2 EC50 = 20 nM, CB1 EC50 > 100 μM). In preclinical animal studies, it demonstrated significant pain reduction at 0.3 and 1 mg/kg po dose in the MIA induced knee injury model and the meniscal tear (MT) model of osteoarthritis.(194)

    3.3.6 6,6-Fused Ring Related Series

    Several independent groups reported CB2 selective modulators comprising 6,6-fused heterocyclic cores (Figures 11 and 12). A series of naphthyridines (e.g., 72) and quinolines (not depicted) were prepared and evaluated for their cannabinoid activity.(196) The lipophilic amide was a requirement for CB2 affinity, and migration of this substituent to the adjacent 2-position resulted in a loss of potency. Compound 72 possessed the best balance between CB2 receptor affinity and selectivity against CB1 (51-fold). Furthermore, 72 demonstrated antinociceptive effects in a mouse hot-plate test at an oral dose of 50 mg/kg.
    A subsequent publication described the migration of the carbonyl to the 2-position of the naphthyridine (e.g., 73) and defined a new chemical series.(197) This modification was well tolerated with respect to potency and afforded improvement in CB2 selectivity. Compound 73 was also reported to exhibit dose-dependent anticancer activity in the human T cell leukemia line Jurkat, by a CB2-mediated mechanism.(197) Interestingly, the cyclohexane trans-conformer had reduced affinity for both cannabinoid receptors (CB2/1Ki = 40 nM/5.3 μM).
    SARs of a closely related 4-quinolone-3-carboxamide CB2 chemotype (e.g., 74, 75) were described by a different academic group.(198, 199)74 is a potent and selective agonist, which demonstrated significant analgesic effects in a mouse formalin test of acute peripheral and inflammatory pain. Specificity was confirmed by full reversal of the antinociceptive response by treatment with AM630(150) (3 mg/kg, ip), a selective CB2 antagonist.(198) A summary of the SAR efforts associated with this chemical series was disclosed in a recent publication.(199) Analogue 75 was found to have a significantly improved CB2/CB1 selectivity profile relative to 74.(199) Maximal effects in the formalin test were achieved at the 1 mg/kg dose, and the effects were significantly attenuated by AM630. Interestingly, removal of either the 6- or 8-substituent caused these analogues to behave as inverse agonists in a CB2 functional assay.(200) Two related series of heteroarylpyridines(201) and oxazinoquinolinecarboxamides(202) have also been described.
    Tetrahydro-1,6-naphthyridinone 76 and a related tetrahydroquinolinone (not depicted) were disclosed as part of a continuing series of patent applications filed by Cara Therapeutics.(203) The cyclobutylmethyl group and a cyclopropylmethyl analogue further define these CB2 agonists. The methylsulfonamide is described as optimal, as larger sulfonamides and amides were not tolerated in this position.
    Cara Therapeutics also disclosed a broader genus of benzo-fused bicycles (e.g., 77, X = S).(204, 205) Their first patent application described benzothiazines as the preferred bicyclic array but also a ring expanded benzothiazepine. A preferred compound from this genus (77, X = S) was reported to cause analgesic effects in a rat model of inflammatory pain. The scope of this genus also includes isosteric replacements of both the amide and sulfonamide.(204) In a subsequent patent application, a closely related pyridoxazine derivative (77, X = O) was reported to modulate cannabinoid receptor activity for the prevention and treatment for pain, inflammation, and pruritis.(205)
    GSK filed a patent application claiming seven specific quinolines (e.g., 78) as selective substrates for the CB2 receptor.(206) In addition to the terminal tetrahydropyran depicted, a pyridine and morpholine are also exemplified. A quinazoline CB2 chemotype (79) is the subject of a separate patent application filed by Kalypsys.(207) The dichlorophenyl array is present in the majority of examples, although a variety of other groups are also exemplified. Additional structural changes include replacement of the piperidine with pyrrolidine, morpholine, thiomorpholine, and homopiperazine.
    Researchers at Merck recently described a series of decahydroquinoline amides as CB2 agonists (e.g., 80 and 81)(208) wherein the isomers depicted in Figure 12 were identified as being optimal. Furthermore, the amide moiety was found to be essential, delivering CB2 selectivity and imparting improved physicochemical properties. The selective CB2 agonist 80 (rCB2/1 EC50 = 6.3 nM/1887 nM) showed a dose-dependent analgesic effect at subcutaneous doses of 10, 30, and 100 mg/kg in a rat model of acute inflammatory pain, whereas CB2 agonist 81 failed to demonstrate efficacy in this study.

    3.3.7 Miscellaneous Bicyclic Cores

    Abbott is developing fused-thiophenes as ligands for the CB2 receptor (82–84, Figure 13).(209-211) These consist of five–five, five–six, and five-seven bicyclic arrays. The first two (e.g., 82 and 83) were selective for CB2 in a binding assay (10- to 1000-fold), and preferred examples showed efficacy at <50 μmol/kg in the SNL neuropathic pain model and the incision model of postoperative pain.(209, 210) Compound 84 is representative of the latest fused-thiophene agonist series to appear from Abbott.(211) This patent application also includes the tetrahydropyridine analogue 84 (X = N) and the cyclohexyl fused thiophene analogue (84, X = CH2). Compound 84 (X = O) demonstrated analgesia in a rat FCA-induced mechanical hyperalgesia model, a skin incision model, and a spinal nerve ligation pain model, when administered intraperitoneally.(212)
    Isatin acylhydrazones such as 85 were investigated by researchers at the MD Anderson Cancer Center and were identified as selective CB2 agonists with potential applications for the treatment of neuropathic pain.(213) Inspiration for this chemical series came from the earlier nonselective cannabinoid agonist 29. Compound 85 exhibited potent antiallodynic effects (ED50 = 5.9 mg/kg) in a spinal nerve ligation neuropathic pain model in rats and did not decrease the exploratory behavior up to an ip dose of 15 mg/kg. In a subsequent publication, the same group disclosed the synthesis and pharmacological evaluation of the dihydrobenzofuran-based, CB2 selective agonist 86 (MDA7).(214) In the reported binding assay, 86 was >23-fold more selective for human CB2 than CB1. On rat receptors, the mean Ki values were 2565 ± 695 and 238 ± 143 nM for CB1 and CB2 receptors, respectively. Compound 86 was shown to dose-dependently attenuate tactile allodynia (ED50 = 7.5 mg/kg, ip) produced by spinal nerve ligation in rats, and the receptor specificity of 86 was confirmed by attenuation of the antiallodynic effects with a CB2 antagonist but not with either a CB1 antagonist or μ-opioid antagonist. This molecule also suppressed mechanical allodynia in a dose-dependent manner in a rat paclitaxel-induced neuropathic pain model (ED50 = 24 mg/kg, ip) and produced a modest transient thermal antinociceptive effect at an ip dose of 10 mg/kg in naive rats. Compound 86 did not affect locomotor activity of rats at the 15 mg/kg ip dose.
    Ironwood recently disclosed three series of CB2 modulators based on a thieno[2,3-b]pyrrole (e.g., 87–89).(215-217) Common to each chemical series is an aryl ketone substituent, which may be located in several positions on the thieno[2,3-b]pyrrole. Representative examples from each series (87, 88, 89) are <100 nM for CB2 and described as “not significant” for CB1 in a GTPγS assay. These agonists also demonstrated dose-dependent anti-inflammatory activity in a rat CFA-induced inflammatory pain model and antinociceptive effects in a mouse phenylbenzquinone (PBQ) induced writhing model.

    3.3.8 Six-Membered Aryls: Pyridine, Pyrimidine, Pyridazine, and Phenyl

    GSK filed several patent applications describing anilinic pyrimidines and pyridines as CB2 modulators (Figure 14, 90–92).(218-221) Compound 90 (GW833972A)(219) was found to reduce dental pain(222) and is described as being useful in combination therapy with a PDE4 inhibitor for treatment of inflammatory and rheumatic diseases.(223) Compound 91 (GW842166X) was later identified and was found to have comparable CB2 affinity. This molecule also had good pharmacokinetics (F = 58%, t1/2 = 3 h, B/P = 0.8), which translated into robust efficacy in the FCA model of inflammatory pain. Compound 91 was efficacious at a relatively low dose (ED50 = 0.1 mg/kg) and caused a full reversal of hyperalgesia at 0.3 mg/kg. This beneficial effect was maintained over 4 days, with no loss of effectiveness due to drug tolerance.(224) This molecule subsequently completed phase II trials for third molar tooth extraction dental pain and for osteoarthritis pain.(225)
    A series of pyridyl-based CB2 agonists later appeared in the literature (e.g., 92).(226) This scaffold choice was motivated in part by the relatively poor aqueous solubility of the pyrimidine motif (91, 2.0 μg/mL at pH 7.4). 92 retained affinity for CB2 and was selective against CB1. Moreover, this compound offered a modest improvement in aqueous solubility (7.0 μg/mL at pH 7.4) and had good exposure and oral bioavailability in rat (AUC(0–t)/dose = 15 min·kg/L, F = 39%, 3.0 mg/kg, po). Compound 92 had an oral ED50 of 0.07 mg/kg in the FCA model of inflammatory pain and caused a full reversal of hyperalgesia at a dose of 0.3 mg/kg po.
    In 2010, Astellas published a patent application describing a series of pyrimidines as useful for treating CB2 mediated diseases (e.g., 93).(227) This chemotype incorporated morpholinoamide and a saturated carbocyclic amine or ether (e.g., bicyclo[2.2.1]heptane group), and examples from this series were reported to be potent and selective CB2 agonists.
    Several CB2 chemotypes comprising a biaryl motif have been developed by GSK (94 and 95, Figure 15).(228, 229) Generally, increased lipophilicity on the biarylpyridine (e.g., 94) improved CB2 potency; however, direct introduction of substituents onto the pyridine ring was detrimental to activity. Compound 94 was >250-fold more potent for CB2 than CB1 and was equal in efficacy to HU-210,(228) a known synthetic cannabinoid.
    Examination of pyridazine analogues led to 95, which was potent and efficacious and had good metabolic stability and high aqueous solubility (>1.0 mg/mL, dihydrochloride salt).(229-231) Furthermore, 95 was orally bioavailable (F = 26%) and achieved a maximal blood concentration of 0.34 μM following a 3.0 mg/kg dose. Compound 95 significantly attenuated FCA-induced hyperalgesia at all doses tested (0.1–1.0 mg/kg) and exhibited a mean brain/plasma ratio of 1.7. Notably, 95 afforded no significant hypothermia at doses up to 300 mg/kg, po.(229)
    Boehringer Ingelheim has also been investigating biaryl CB2 agonists and identified chiral morpholine 96.(232) This agonist was found to be a 1000 times more active at the CB2 receptor relative to the CB1 subtype. Conversely, the (R)-morpholine isomer was found to function as an inverse agonist of the CB2 receptor. Other heterocycles such as piperazine, thiomorpholine, and thiomorpholine dioxide were also examined, but these analogues were less potent.
    Alternatives to the biaryl motif were examined with the hope of reducing potential nonspecific protein binding in vivo.(233) Compound 97 is potent and selective agonist of the CB2 receptor that lacks a biaryl feature.(232) Interestingly, 97 was not active in a [3H]CP-55,940 binding assay (hCB2Ki > 10 μM), possibly indicating that this molecule is acting at an allosteric site. Compounds 96 and 97 both demonstrated oral efficacy in a mouse zymosan induced paw inflammation (ZIPI) model, which confirmed anti-inflammatory properties associated with CB2.(232, 234)
    Compound 98 is a CB2 agonist being investigated by N.V. Organon (now part of Merck).(235) Oral administration of 98 attenuated mechanical allodynia in a dose-dependent manner in a rat model of neuropathic pain, with a minimum effective dose (MED) equal to 6.3 mg/kg po. This compound also reversed mechanical hyperalgesia (MED = 1.83 mg/kg po) in a rat model of CFA induced inflammatory pain.
    Researchers at Merck recently published on the discovery of (4-(pyridine-2-yl)benzyl)imidazolidine-2,4-diones as selective CB2 agonists (e.g 99).(236) Their extensive optimization effort focused on overcoming pharmacokinetic and hERG liabilities associated with this chemotype. An optimized lead from within this series (99) exhibited improved metabolic stability (HLM/RLM t1/2 > 70 min, CLint < 20 μL min–1 mg–1) and pharmacokinetics (Cmax = 3.8 μM, t1/2 = 1.7 h, and F = 100% at 5.0 mg/kg, po) and demonstrated a dose-dependent antinociceptive effect in the rat spinal nerve ligation model of neuropathic pain. Relatively high free plasma levels (>1900 nM) were required to produce significant antinociception, which the authors suggest may be due to low CNS exposure (B/P = 0.05). Additionally, this optimized lead was devoid of interaction at the hERG channel at a 1.0 μM test concentration in a [3H]dofetilide binding assay.
    Several benzamide-derived CB2 agonists have been described in the literature (Figure 16).(237-242) The (S)-fenchyl analogue 100 was found to provide a 33-fold window of selectivity versus CB1 in a [3H]CP-55,940 binding assay and did not produce catalepsy at doses of 6 and 10 mg/kg when administered intraperitoneally.(237) Furthermore, 100 produced significant antiallodynic activity in the L5 SNL rat model of neuropathic pain at a dose of 3 mg/kg ip and was efficacious at a dose of 10 mg/kg ip in the hind paw incision model of postoperative pain. Unfortunately, development of 100 appears limited because of its poor oral bioavailability.
    SAR studies performed on a related series led to the identification of compound 101 (R1 = CH3) as a potent agonist of the CB2 receptor (EC50 = 4 nM, cAMP).(238) This molecule was a weak agonist of the CB1 receptor, having an EC50 > 9.3 μM in the cyclase assay. The methyl group of 101 proved to be optimal, with larger groups being much less well tolerated with respect to potency. Replacement of the amide linker with isosteric oxadiazoles was described in a separate invention disclosure.(239) Consistent with its in vitro profile, 101 exhibited anti-inflammatory properties when tested in a mouse zymosan induced paw inflammation (ZIPI) study.(240)
    Reversing the amide linkage and introducing the smaller cyclopropylamide motif led to a more CB2 selective molecule (102).(241) Compound 102 demonstrated antiallodynic activity in the hind paw incision model of postoperative pain when delivered intraperitoneally (30 mg/kg), but efficacy was not observed with oral administration. The lack of oral efficacy may be due to metabolic instability, as only 2% of 102 remained after incubating for 30 min with rat liver microsomes. Encouragingly, the xylene analogue (102, R = CH3) improved metabolic stability while maintaining CB2 potency and selectivity.(242) Further efforts led to the discovery of N-(3-morpholinomethyl)arylamides,(243, 244) wherein 103 was found to possess the best selectivity (190-fold) and metabolic stability (rat liver microsomes: 29% remaining after 30 min.). This molecule produced a significant antiallodynic effect at a dose of 10 mg/kg ip in the hindpaw incision model of postoperative pain, but like its predecessor, efficacy was not observed with oral administration.(243)
    Incorporation of a pyridine (e.g., 104) was found to improve the physicochemical properties of this series and increase metabolic stability in human and rat liver microsomes (rat liver microsomes: 43% remaining at 30 min.).(244) Correspondingly, 104 was found to have appreciable oral bioavailability in rats (F = 57%). Despite promising pharmacokinetics, this molecule exhibited weak antiallodynic activity in a rat model of neuropathic pain, even at 100 mg/kg oral dose. Further efforts to enhance in vivo potency are currently underway.

    3.3.9 Five-Membered Heterocycles

    Researchers from Taisho Pharmaceuticals have disclosed a series of thiazoylidene CB2 agonists (Figure 17).(245, 246) Sulfonamide 105 was found to be a full CB2 agonist with selectivity of 106-fold over the CB1 receptor.(245) Unfortunately, this molecule exhibited poor metabolic stability in human liver microsomes (35% remaining at 15 min.). A subsequent publication described a series of amides that were reported to address some of the liabilities associated with the sulfonamide series. Compound 106 exhibited improved selectivity for CB2 (270-fold), increased metabolic stability (human liver microsomes: 93% remaining at 15 min), and acceptable rat pharmacokinetics (AUC0–24h = 326 ng·h/mL, Cmax = 43.1 ng/mL, t1/2 = 4.8 h, F = 52%, 3 mg/kg, po).(246)
    An analogous pyrazole series was the focus of a report published in 2008 (e.g., 107).(247) Incorporation of the pyrazole reduced the overall lipophilicity of this chemical series and led to an improvement in aqueous solubility (107, 5.9 mg/100 mL). Compound 107 also had improved affinity and selectivity versus the CB1 subtype (1380-fold). Rat pharmacokinetic studies showed good exposure (10 mg/kg po: AUC0–8h = 2160 ng·h/mL, Cmax = 545 ng/mL) and an acceptable half-life (t1/2 = 2.5 h). A dose dependent (10 and 30 mg/kg po) antinociceptive effect was observed in the rat Randall–Selitto model of inflammatory pain, and the effect lasted >3 h postdose.
    Abbott reported another thiazolylidene series comprising a bulky cycloalkylcarboxamide group (e.g., 108, A-836339).(248) Compound 108 exhibited subnanomolar potency in competition binding assays for human and rat CB2, with good selectivity against the human (425-fold) and rat (189-fold) CB1 receptors. In functional assays, the potency of 108 (EC50 = 1.6 nM) was similar to that of 35 (EC50 = 0.71 nM). Compound 108 showed minimal off-target activity (<50% inhibition at 10 μM) in a 74 receptor CEREP panel and demonstrated dose-dependent efficacy in several preclinical rodent pain models such as FCA-induced inflammatory pain (ED50 = 1.96 μmol/kg), skin incision (ED50 = 12.0 μmol/kg), capsaicin-induced mechanical hyperalgesia (ED50 = 10.4 μmol/kg), and a chronic constriction injury model of neuropathic pain (ED50 = 12.9 μmol/kg). Despite a significant preference for the CB2 receptor, 108 showed a CB1-associated reduction in horizontal locomotor activity at the 15 and 45 μmol/kg doses, which was blocked by treatment with the CB1 receptor antagonist 5-(4-chlorophenyl)-1-(2,4-dichlorophenyl)-4-methyl-N-(piperidin-1-yl)-1H-pyrazole-3-carboxamide (SR141716A).(249)
    Two closely related series of thiazolidine analogues (e.g., 109) were described in subsequent patent applications.(250, 251) Selectivity ratios were reported to be 10- to 1000-fold in favor of CB2, and several examples were efficacious at doses of <50 μmol/kg in an incision model of postoperative pain, a spinal nerve ligation model of neuropathic pain, and a capsaicin induced mechanical hypersensitivity study.
    Additional SAR studies afforded other potent and selective CB2 ligands that consisted of a diverse number of five-membered heterocycles such as pyrazoylidene, triazoylidene, thiazoylidene, and thiadaizoylidenearylcarboxamide analogues (e.g., 110–112).(252-254) Extensive SAR of the phenyl ring showed that lipophilic substitutents such as those depicted (e.g., CF3, Cl) are beneficial for activity, as are polar alkoxy or aminoalkyl groups adjacent to the amide (e.g., 110, 111, 112).(252-254) Compound 110 was selective for CB2 in functional assays (>57000-fold vs CB1) and had Ki values of 27 and 4.4 nM in a competition binding assay for human and rat CB2 receptors, respectively. This molecule was orally bioavailable in rat (F = 46%) and had a low clearance value (CL = 1.8 L h–1 kg–1) and a relatively long intravenous half-life (t1/2 = 2.3 h, iv).(252)
    A series of (3-aryl)oxadiazoles (e.g., 113, Figure 18) emerged from a hit to lead effort carried out by researchers at Amgen.(255) This chemotype is further defined by a linear alkylamine in the oxadiazole 5-position.(256) The 3-aryl group was found to be an important component driving CB2 potency, with the 2,4-disubstitution pattern being optimal. Compound 113 showed moderate metabolic stability (Clint = 38 μL min–1 mg–1 in HLM) but suffered from poor oral bioavailability in rat (F = 2%, 10 mg/kg po).(255)
    A related series of 2,4-diphenyl-1H-imidazoles (e.g., 114) was disclosed by Merck.(257) The terminal piperidine is influential in terms of potency, selectivity, and efficacy, and the unsubstituted piperidine (depicted) provides the best balance of these properties. An alternative 4-aryl substitution pattern (e.g., 2,3-dichloro) was required in this chemical series to maintain good potency and selectivity for the CB2 receptor.
    Several other five-membered heterocycles comprising a tert-butyl group have also appeared (e.g., 115–117,(258-262)119–122(264-271)). Pyrazolylamide 115 is representative of a CB2 agonist chemotype reported by Amgen. Compound 115 has a good pharmacokinetic profile in rat, with an AUC0–inf of 3570 ng·h/mL, a Cmax of 971 ng/mL, and an oral bioavailability value equal to 43% at a 10 mg/kg dose.(258)
    Boehringer Ingelheim disclosed several five-membered heterocyclic analogues (116–119),(259-264) with the isoxazole motif being superior with respect to CB2 potency. Alkylsulfone 116 is the most potent CB2 agonist disclosed in their first disclosure, and cycloalkylsulfones (e.g., cyclohexane, cycloheptane, tetrahydropyran, etc.) also retain subnanomolar CB2 activity. Reduced CB1 activation was achieved by introduction of a more polar element on the tert-butyl group, such as hydroxyl (e.g., 117).(260-262)
    In a related series of 1,2,4-triazoles, an aryl substituent in this position (118) confers excellent CB2 potency and selectivity.(261) Several sulfonamide analogues comprising a small alkylamine or a cycloalkyl amine (e.g., azetidine, pyrrolidine) were shown to retain high CB2 affinity in a separate disclosure.(263)
    A CB2 chemotype bearing an amino linkage was also disclosed (119)(264) and afforded compounds with improved physicochemical properties. This modification, however, did reduce CB2 activity relative to the sulfonyl analogues.
    A 1,4-diazepane motif is the focus of a patent application describing the utility of CB2 modulators in the treatment of inflammation. Of the examples provided, 120 is the most potent agonist disclosed.(265) The thiazole appears to drive activity in this series, as isoxazole, pyrazole, pyridine, and phenyl are less active at the CB2 receptor. A subsequent application, however, features a benzoxazole instead of thiazole, and these analogues appear to be very potent CB2 agonists (EC50 = 0.017 nM).(266)
    Several recent publications describe the causal relationship between the diazepamylamide and pharmaceutical properties.(267, 268) One study focused on improving metabolic stability and pharmacokinetics by targeting analogues with reduced relative lipophilicity. Tetrahydropyran 121 (Figure 19) was the best molecule in this respect, having improved stability (HLM t1/2 > 120 min), a clean CYP profile (2D6, 2C9, 3A4, >30 μM), and improved rat pharmacokinetics (F = 28%, AUC0–inf = 1.38 μmol h–1 L–1, Cmax = 1.76 μg/mL, 10 μmol/kg, po). These improvements, however, were reported to be partially offset by a reduction in CB2 activity.(267)
    Boehringer Ingelheim identified several CB2 chemotypes comprising azetidines (122, n = 1, EC50 = 0.67 nM),(269) pyrrolidines (122, n = 2, EC50 = 0.067 nM),(270) piperidines (122, n = 3, EC50 = 0.093 nM),(271) and azapines (122, n = 4, EC50 = NA).(271) These ligands were further defined by an aryl (e.g., pyridine) or an alkyl (e.g., cyclopropylmethyl) group present on the nitrogen of cyclic amine to induce high affinity for CB2. CB2 activity was highly dependent on the stereochemistry at the chiral center, with the (R)-isomer of 122 having significantly reduced CB2 affinity (EC50 = 173 nM).

    3.3.10 Miscellaneous Structures

    2-Arylimino-5,6-dihydro-4H-1,3-thiazines (123, 124) have been described as a novel class of cannabinoid agonists by researchers at Shionogi & Co.(272-275) This cannabinoid chemotype is further defined by a gem-dialkyl feature that appears to be critical for maintaining affinity at this receptor. The gem-dimethyl analogue 123 (Figure 20) is selective for CB2 versus the CB1 subtype (550-fold); however, this molecule was not orally bioavailable and possessed a short half-life in vivo. Nevertheless, compound 123 was efficacious in the mouse formalin test when administrated subcutaneously, and analgesia was reversed upon administration of a CB2 antagonist (SR144528).(272) In a subsequent patent application, successful replacement of the phenyl group with a five-membered heterocycle was achieved.(273)
    An orally bioavailable (F = 20%), spirocyclic variant (124, X = S) was later disclosed. This compound retained good activity for the CB2 receptor; however, it failed to show an analgesic effect in the mouse formalin test when administered orally.(274) A series of oxazine analogues (124, X = O) were claimed in a separate application(275) and appear to be less selective for CB2 than the thiazines.
    Shionogi completed clinical trials for the treatment of atopic dermatitis with a CB2 selective agonist (125, S-777469)(276) and recently disclosed the structure of their candidate compound.(277) In a preclinical animal study, 125 demonstrated a significant antipruritic effect in a mouse scratching test.
    Allergan disclosed a new CB2 chemotype based on a pyridazin-3-one ring, wherein the tetramethylcyclohexyl substituted analogue 126 was preferred.(278) Additionally, the aminoalkyl residue was found to be important for potency, as aryl replacements in the 2-position produced a total loss of receptor affinity. Compound 126 was determined to have an EC50 of 820 nM in the mouse isolated vas deferens (MVD) bioassay, which is a highly sensitive and quantitative CB1 functional assay.

    3.3.11 Tricyclic Cores

    Several groups have sought to develop conformationally restricted tricyclic arrays with affinity for the CB2 receptor (Figure 21). Pyrazole 127 belongs to one of the first tricycles to be described.(279) This CB2 selective series was designed and synthesized using CB1 antagonist SR141716A as a starting point. Interestingly, rigidifying SR141716A resulted in a significant loss of CB1 affinity and a gain in CB2 agonist activity. The preferred compound 127 (X = N, GP-1a) exhibited a high degree of affinity and selectivity (9810-fold) for the CB2 receptor.(279) SAR studies of other analogues, such as 1-(2′,4′-dichlorophenyl)-6-methyl-N-cyclohexylamine-1,4-dihydroindeno[1,2-c]pyrazole-3-carboxamide (127, X = CH, NESS400) and N′-arylcarbohydrazides, were the subject of a subsequent publication.(280) Compound 127 (X = CH) significantly attenuated neuropathic mechanical allodynia and thermal hyperalgesia at doses of 1 and 2 mg/kg (ip) in mice with spared nerve injury (SNI). This effect was dose dependent, and receptor specificity was confirmed by concomitant treatment with a CB2 antagonist.(281)
    The synthesis and in vitro characterization of a benzoquinolizinone compound 128 (Sch35966) was described by the Schering-Plough research group.(282) Compound 128 was found to be a potent CB2 agonist in four different species, with Ki values of 6.8 nM (human), 5.4 nM (monkey), 2.4 nM (rat), and 4.8 nM (mouse). Furthermore, this compound exhibited at least 450-fold selectivity versus CB1 in all species examined.
    A series of octahydrophenanthridine based CB2 modulators (129) is the subject of a patent application from Cara Therapeutics.(283) In the mouse acetic acid induced writhing assay, 129 demonstrated analgesic activity at a subcutaneous dose of 10 mg/kg. This beneficial effect was, however, accompanied by a reduction of body temperature (−0.1 °C).
    A tricyclic series comprising conformationally constrained tetrahydropyrroloindole (130) was identified and assessed in vitro.(284) SAR studies showed the sulfonamide produced higher CB2 binding affinities than the corresponding amide or N-alkyl analogues. Furthermore, the piperidine depicted afforded the highest CB2 binding affinity of all groups examined in this position. Compound 130 is described as a potent (hCB2 EC50 = 1.7 nM) and full CB2 agonist (Emax = 107% relative to WIN55,212-2) as determined in the GTPγ[35S] assay and possessed the best binding selectivity (>350-fold vs CB1).
    Substituted oxindole sulfonamides (e.g., 131) or arylsulfones were reported by Wyeth.(285, 286) This chemical series shares much of the same SAR with the previously described benzimidazoles (Figure 6), particularly with regard to preferred substituents in the 1- and 5-position of the oxindole.
    Arena recently disclosed a novel class of conformationally restricted tricyclic pyrazoles with significantly improved CB2 selectivity relative to the previously described bicyclic (Figure 9) and tricyclic pyrazoles (Figure 21).(287) Representative compound 132 is one such molecule that did not display CB1 associated effects when administered orally at 100 mg/kg to rats. Other selected compounds were evaluated in several rodent pain models.

    4 Clinical Trials

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    A number of pharmaceutical companies have reported entering development with CB2 agonists mostly for the treatment of pain. Pharmos, in one of the earliest reports, tested their candidate 17, a 37-fold selective CB2 agonist, intravenously in a third molar dental extraction phase IIa trial. Results of this trial were confounding wherein the lowest 12 mg dose showed significant effects, whereas two higher doses of 24 and 48 mg failed to achieve significance. In a separate phase IIa study for induced pain in healthy volunteers, 48 mg dose of 17 was not effective in reducing capsaicin-induced pain but did show activity in mechanical and thermal hyperalgesia in normal skin(94, 95) Future development efforts with this compound have been discontinued.
    GlaxoSmithKline completed clinical trials for dental pain (third molar tooth extraction) and osteoarthritis pain with their clinical candidate 91. The latter trial was a double-blind, two-period, and placebo controlled crossover phase II study in patients with osteoarthritis over 6–8 weeks. The primary outcome measure was change in pain scores from baseline to the end of the study using WOMAC questionnaires. Secondary outcome measures include assessments of arthritis condition, heat pain threshold, and tolerance, global assessments of condition, mobility tests, and use of rescue medication. The results of these trials were not disclosed, and the clinical program appears to have been discontinued.
    Glenmark Pharmaceuticals reported successful completion of phase I trial in Europe with their candidate (4S,7R)-1-(2,4-difluorophenyl)-N-(1,1-dimethylethyl)-4,5,6,7-tetrahydro-4,7-methano-1H-indazole-3-carboxamide (GRC10693) demonstrating both safety and efficacy. A phase II trial was planned for 2009 according to the company’s Web site; however, no further development has been reported for this agonist to date.
    The current status of the CB2 agonist development field is reflected in Table 4. A significant number of organizations have advanced to phase 1 and phase 2 clinical testing with new molecular entities, including JB Therapeutics, Kyowa Hakko Kirin, Eli Lilly, Astra Zeneca, Shionogi, and Abbott.
    Table 4. CB2 Agonists in Development
    companydrugMoAcountrystatusindicationref

    Kyowa Hakko KirinKHK6188bCB2 agonistU.S.phase 2postherpetic neuralgia289
    Abbott (Abbvie)ABT-521bCB2 agonistU.S.phase 1pain290
